intro: Nemacladus secundiflorus var. robbinsii, commonly known as Robbins' sandverbena, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its narrow, lance-shaped leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is often found in coastal dunes or open woodlands. It produces pale blue to violet flowers that bloom in the summer months, and it is adapted to withstand salt spray and sandy conditions. This variety is considered rare and is of interest to botanists due to its unique ecological niche.
